ConfigurationName: Update Microsoft Defender Antivirus definitions in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: This status indicates that Microsoft Defender Antivirus definitions are not up to date.
RiskDescription: Not having the latest antivirus definitions could potentially expose you to recently discovered viruses.

ConfigurationName: Turn on PUA protection in block mode
ConfigurationDescription: Enabling Potentially Unwanted Application (PUA) protection in block mode will block and automatically quarantine potentially unwanted applications. PUA protection blocking takes effect on endpoint clients after the next signature update or computer restart.
RiskDescription: Not having PUA in Block mode enabled leaves your machines vulnerable to unwanted applications with potentially malicious behavior.

ConfigurationName: Onboard devices to Microsoft Defender for Endpoint
ConfigurationDescription: Ensures that discovered devices in your network are protected by an endpoint security solution. Onboarding devices increases visibility and control of networks.
RiskDescription: Devices inside the network that are not yet onboarded might be non-compliant with security levels recommended by your organization. These devices might introduce risk or open the network for attacks if they become compromised.

ConfigurationName: Enable EDR in block mode
ConfigurationDescription: Enable EDR in block mode to block post breach malicious behavior on the device through behavior blocking and containment capabilities when Windows Defender Anti-Virus is not the Primary Anti-Virus on the device. Learn more about EDR block
RiskDescription: Not enabling this capability leaves your endpoint vulnerable to malicious attacks that might not have been identified by the 3rd party primary antivirus.

ConfigurationName: Disable Microsoft Defender Firewall notifications when programs are blocked for Private profile
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Microsoft Defender Firewall with Advanced Security display notifications to the user when a program is blocked from receiving inbound connections.
RiskDescription: Firewall notifications can be complex and may confuse the end users, who would not be able to address the alert.

ConfigurationName: Disable Solicited Remote Assistance
ConfigurationDescription: Remote assistance allows another user to view or take control of the local session of a user.  Solicited assistance is help that is specifically requested by the local user.
RiskDescription: This may allow unauthorized parties access to the resources on the computer

ConfigurationName: Set Microsoft Defender SmartScreen Microsoft Edge site and download checking to block or warn
ConfigurationDescription:
Microsoft Defender SmartScreen provides warning messages to help protect your employees from potential phishing scams and malicious software.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1703 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: If disabled, employees will not be warned or prevented from accessing malicious websites or downloading unsafe software from the web.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Local Security Authority (LSA) protection'
ConfigurationDescription: Forces LSA to run as Protected Process Light (PPL).
RiskDescription: If LSA isn't running as a protected process, attackers could easily abuse the low process integrity for attacks (such as Pass-the-Hash).

ConfigurationName: Enable cloud-delivered protection
ConfigurationDescription: Indicates that Microsoft Defender Antivirus cloud-delivered protection is not enabled. Cloud-delivered protection service provides very important protection against malware on your endpoints and across your network. Learn more about cloud-delivered protection
RiskDescription: The Windows Defender Antivirus cloud service (also referred to as Microsoft Advanced Protection Service - MAPS) is a mechanism for delivering updated protection to your network and endpoints. When cloud-deliverad protection is disabled, Microsoft AI and cloud resources cannot be harnessed to provide near real-time protection to your endpoints and the risk of new and emerging threats is increased.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Autoplay for non-volume devices'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether autoplay for non-volume devices (such as Media Transfer Protocol (MTP) devices) is enabled or disabled.
RiskDescription: An attacker could use this feature to launch a program to damage a client computer or data on the computer.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Apply UAC restrictions to local accounts on network logons'
ConfigurationDescription:
With User Account Control enabled, filtering the privileged token for built-in administrator accounts will prevent the elevated privileges of these accounts from being used over the network.
This recommendation is not applicable for organizations which use local password management solution (like LAPS) to protect local accounts for remote administration and support.
RiskDescription: A compromised local administrator account can provide means for an attacker to move laterally between domain systems.

ConfigurationName: Disable merging of local Microsoft Defender Firewall connection rules with group policy firewall rules for the Public profile
ConfigurationDescription: Controls whether local administrators are allowed to create connection security rules that apply together with connection security rules configured by Group Policy.
RiskDescription: Users with administrative privileges might create firewall rules that expose the system to remote attack. Local connection rules should not be merged with Group Policy settings on a public network to prevent Group Policy settings from being changed and weakened.

ConfigurationName: Disable the built-in Guest account
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether the built-in Guest account is disabled.
RiskDescription: The built-in Guest  account is a well-known account subject to attack by malicious actors. Unauthorized anonymous network users can use this account to log on as Guest with no password authentication. Such unauthenticated users could then gain access to all resources that are accessible to the Guest account over the network, so network shared folders with permissions that allow access to the Everyone user group will be accessible over the network and could lead to leakage or corruption of data.

ConfigurationName: Secure Microsoft Defender Firewall public profile
ConfigurationDescription:
Microsoft Defender Firewall is designed to keep hackers and malicious software from gaining access to your device through a network or the Internet.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2008 R2, 2012 R2, 2016 and 2019.
RiskDescription: If the firewall is turned off all traffic will be able to access the system and an attacker may be more easily able to remotely exploit a weakness in a network service.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Hide Option to Enable or Disable Updates'
ConfigurationDescription: Controls whether to hide the user interface (UI) options to enable or disable Office automatic updates from users.
RiskDescription: Prevent users from disabling automatic updates for Office.

ConfigurationName: Set 'Remote Desktop security level' to 'TLS'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines the method used by the server and client for authentication prior to a remote desktop connection being established.
RiskDescription: If the authentication level isn't secure enough, an attacker could gain remote access to the machine

ConfigurationName: Block all Office applications from creating child processes
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule blocks Office apps from creating child processes. This includes Word, Excel, PowerPoint, OneNote, and Access.

Note: Some legitimate line-of-business applications might also use behaviors like this, including spawning a command prompt or using PowerShell to configure registry settings.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Creating child processes is a typical malware behaviour that can be exploited in various ways, especially for attacks that abuse Office as a vector, using VBA macros and exploit code to download and attempt to run additional malicious payload.

ConfigurationName: Block executable files from running unless they meet a prevalence, age, or trusted list criterion
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule blocks executable files (such as .exe, .dll, .scr) from launching unless they either meet prevalence or age criteria, or they're in a trusted list or exclusion list.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Allowing executables that have not yet established sufficient trust and validation to be executed, increases your exposure to potentially malicious applications.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Domain member: Digitally encrypt or sign secure channel data (always)'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether all secure channel traffic that is initiated by the domain member must be signed or encrypted.
RiskDescription: When a computer joins a domain, a computer account is created. After it joins the domain, the computer uses the password for that account to create a secure channel with the Domain controller for its domain every time that it restarts. Requests that are sent on the secure channel are authenticated and sensitive information such as passwords are encrypted but the channel is not integrity-checked, and not all information is encrypted.

ConfigurationName: Require authentication for VNC management interface
ConfigurationDescription: VNC as a management interface allows admins to remotely manage devices. Without an authentication requirement, any user who has network access to these devices may compromise them. Update the device configuration to require authentication.
RiskDescription: An attacker may be able to take full control of devices over the network if unauthenticated admin access is allowed.

ConfigurationName: Prohibit use of Internet Connection Sharing on your DNS domain network
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether an existing internet connection, such as through wireless, can be shared and used by other systems essentially creating a mobile hotspot.
RiskDescription: This exposes the system sharing the connection to others with potentially malicious purpose.

ConfigurationName: Block persistence through WMI event subscription
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule allows admins to have more control over WMI repository persistence.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1903 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Fileless threats employ various tactics to stay hidden, to avoid being seen in the file system, and to gain periodic execution control. Some threats can abuse the WMI repository and event model to stay hidden.

ConfigurationName: Set 'Minimum password age' to '1 or more day(s)'
ConfigurationDescription:
Determines the number of days that you must use a password before you can change it.

This security control is only assessed for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later.
RiskDescription: Using this policy setting with the Enforce password history setting prevents the easy reuse of old passwords. For example, if you configure the Enforce password history setting to ensure that users cannot reuse any of their last 12 passwords, they could change their password 13 times in a few minutes and reuse the password they started with.

ConfigurationName: Use advanced protection against ransomware
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule scans executable files entering the system to determine whether they're trustworthy.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: This provides an extra layer of protection against files that closely resemble ransomware, by blocking them from running, unless they're in a trusted list or exclusion list.

ConfigurationName: Set 'Interactive logon: Machine inactivity limit' to '1-900 seconds'
ConfigurationDescription:
Determines the amount of inactivity time (in seconds) of a logon session, beyond which the screen saver will run, locking the session.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later.
RiskDescription: An unattended device that remains unlocked, exposes the device to unauthorized use by malicious attackers who can exploit this to hijack the device, execute malicious code, or access sensitive data.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key'
ConfigurationDescription: When this policy setting is enabled, a secure channel can only be established with Domain controllers that are capable of encrypting secure channel data with a strong (128-bit) session key.
RiskDescription: Session keys that are used to establish secure channel communications between Domain controllers and member computers are much stronger in Windows 2000 than they were in previous Microsoft operating systems. Whenever possible, you should take advantage of these stronger session keys to help protect secure channel communications from attacks that attempt to hijack network sessions and eavesdropping.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Microsoft Defender for Endpoint Plug-in for WSL'
ConfigurationDescription: The Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) 2, which replaces the previous version of WSL (supported by Microsoft Defender for Endpoint without a plug-in), provides a Linux environment that is seamlessly integrated with Windows yet isolated using virtualization technology. The MDE plug-in for WSL enables Defender for Endpoint to provide more visibility into all running WSL containers, by plugging into the isolated subsystem.
RiskDescription: If the MDE plug-in for WSL is disabled MDE does not get visibility into the activity inside the WSL2 containers.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Block third party cookies'
ConfigurationDescription: Chrome allows cookies to be set by web page elements that are not from the domain in the user's address bar. Enabling this feature prevents third party cookies from being set.
RiskDescription: Blocking third party cookies can help protect a user's privacy by eliminating a number of website tracking cookies.

ConfigurationName: Change service account to avoid cached password in windows registry
ConfigurationDescription: Determines the existence on the machine of one or more services, which are configured to run with account that stores its password in reversible encryption in the registry.
RiskDescription: An attacker can exploit this misconfiguration in order to dump services accounts passwords and gain access to credentials.

ConfigurationName: Set 'Enforce password history' to '24 or more password(s)'
ConfigurationDescription:
Determines the number of unique new passwords that are required before an old password can be reused in association with a user account.

This security control is only assessed for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later.
RiskDescription: Password reuse is an important concern in any organization. Many users want to reuse the same password for their account over a long period of time.

ConfigurationName: Fix Windows Defender Antivirus cloud service connectivity
ConfigurationDescription: Indicates that a device is failing to communicate with the Windows Defender Antivirus cloud service.
RiskDescription: Failed communication between the device and the cloud service means that cloud-delivered protection against malware on your endpoints and across the network will not function properly.

ConfigurationName: Disable SMBv1 server
ConfigurationDescription: Disabling SMBv1 support may prevent access to file or print sharing resources with systems or devices that only support SMBv1.
RiskDescription: SMBv1 is a legacy protocol that uses the MD5 algorithm as part of SMB. MD5 is known to be vulnerable to a number of attacks such as collision and preimage attacks as well as not being FIPS compliant.

ConfigurationName: Enable Microsoft Defender Antivirus cloud-delivered protection for Linux
ConfigurationDescription: Indicates that Microsoft Defender Antivirus cloud-delivered protection is not enabled. Cloud-delivered protection service provides very important protection against malware on your endpoints and across your network. Learn more about cloud-delivered protection
RiskDescription: The Windows Defender Antivirus cloud service (also referred to as Microsoft Advanced Protection Service - MAPS) is a mechanism for delivering updated protection to your network and endpoints. When cloud-deliverad protection is disabled, Microsoft AI and cloud resources cannot be harnessed to provide near real-time protection to your endpoints and the risk of new and emerging threats is increased.

ConfigurationName: Disable Anonymous enumeration of shares
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether anonymous logon users (null session connections) are allowed to list all account names and enumerate all shared resources
RiskDescription: Allowing this can provide a map of potential points to attack the system.

ConfigurationName: Disable Microsoft Defender Firewall notifications when programs are blocked for Domain profile
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Microsoft Defender Firewall with Advanced Security display notifications to the user when a program is blocked from receiving inbound connections.
RiskDescription: Firewall notifications can be complex and may confuse the end users, who would not be able to address the alert.

ConfigurationName: Update Microsoft Defender Antivirus definitions for Linux
ConfigurationDescription: This status indicates that Microsoft Defender Antivirus definitions are not up to date.
RiskDescription: Not having the latest antivirus definitions could potentially expose you to recently discovered viruses.

ConfigurationName: Block Win32 API calls from Office macros
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule prevents using Win32 APIs in VBA macros.

Note: Most organizations don't use this functionality, but might still rely on using other macro capabilities.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Malicious code can abuse the ability to execute routines in the Win 32 dynamic link library from macros.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Require additional authentication at startup'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether BitLocker requires additional authentication each time the computer starts, and whether you are using BitLocker with or without a Trusted Platform Module (TPM).
RiskDescription: TPM without use of a PIN will only validate early boot components and does not require a user to enter any additional authentication information. If a computer is lost or stolen in this configuration, BitLocker will not provide any additional measure of protection beyond what is provided by native Windows authentication unless the early boot components are tampered with or the encrypted drive is removed from the machine.

ConfigurationName: Disable insecure administration protocol – Telnet
ConfigurationDescription: Devices using Telnet are exposed to malicious threats because Telnet is not a secure and encrypted communication protocol. Use secure protocols such as SSH to administer devices.
RiskDescription: Allowing devices to use Telnet increases their exposure to credential theft

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Enumerate administrator accounts on elevation'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether the user needs to provide both the administrator username and password to elevate a running application, or if the system displays a list of administrator accounts to choose from.
RiskDescription: Enumeration of administrator accounts when elevating can provide part of the logon information to an unauthorized user, making attacks easier.

ConfigurationName: Update Microsoft Defender Antivirus definitions
ConfigurationDescription: This status indicates that Microsoft Defender Antivirus definitions are not up to date.
RiskDescription: Not having the latest antivirus definitions could potentially expose you to recently discovered viruses.

ConfigurationName: Enable Microsoft Defender Antivirus real-time behavior monitoring
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Microsoft Defender Antivirus monitors file processes, file and registry changes, and other events on your endpoints for suspicious and known malicious activity.
RiskDescription: Disabling behavior monitoring will reduce your ability to detect suspicious activity that could indicate a breach.

ConfigurationName: Turn on Microsoft Defender for Endpoint sensor
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint sensor embedded in Windows collect and process behavioral signals from the operating system and sends this sensor data to your private, isolated, cloud instance of Microsoft Defender for Endpoint
RiskDescription: The Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service will not be able to determine the security state of machines that are not sending sensor data.

ConfigurationName: Set default behavior for 'AutoRun' to 'Enabled: Do not execute any autorun commands'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Autorun commands are allowed to execute. Autorun commands are generally stored in autorun.inf files. They often launch the installation program or other routines.
RiskDescription: Allowing autorun commands to execute may introduce malicious code to a system without user intervention or awareness. Configuring this setting prevents autorun commands from executing.

ConfigurationName: Disable Flash on Adobe Reader DC
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Adobe Reader will render Flash content.
RiskDescription: Flash is an unsecure technology with many known vulnerabilities, it is recommended to avoid using it.

ConfigurationName: Set Microsoft Defender SmartScreen app and file checking to block or warn
ConfigurationDescription:
SmartScreen helps protect PCs by warning users before running potentially malicious programs downloaded from the Internet.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1703 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: If disabled, employees will not be warned or prevented from running potentially malicious programs downloaded from the internet.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Network access: Let Everyone permissions apply to anonymous users'
ConfigurationDescription:
Determines whether anonymous network users have the same rights and permissions as the built-in 'Everyone' group..

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1709 or later.
RiskDescription: If not disabled, unauthorized users could anonymously access shared resources,  list account names and shared resources and use the information to attempt to guess passwords, perform social engineering attacks, or launch DoS attacks.

ConfigurationName: Fix unquoted service path for Windows services
ConfigurationDescription: Determines the existence on the machine of one or more services, which are configured with a path to executable that contains spaces and also isn't surrounded by quotation marks..
RiskDescription: An attacker can exploit this misconfiguration in order to perform path interception to gain escalation of privileges and persistency on the machine.

ConfigurationName: Disable Microsoft Defender Firewall notifications when programs are blocked for Public profile
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Microsoft Defender Firewall with Advanced Security display notifications to the user when a program is blocked from receiving inbound connections.
RiskDescription: Firewall notifications can be complex and may confuse the end users, who would not be able to address the alert.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Allow Basic authentication' for WinRM Client
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether the Windows Remote Management (WinRM) client uses Basic authentication.
RiskDescription: Basic authentication uses plain text passwords that could be used by an attacker to compromise a system.

ConfigurationName: Disable sending unencrypted password to third-party SMB servers
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether the SMB redirector will send unencrypted (plain text) passwords when authenticating to third-party SMB servers that do not support password encryption.
RiskDescription: Sending plain text passwords across the network, when authenticating to an SMB server, reduces the overall security of the environment and introduces a significant security risk. Check with the vendor of the SMB server to see if there is a way to support encrypted password authentication.

ConfigurationName: Change service executable path to a common protected location
ConfigurationDescription: Determines the existence on the machine of one or more services, which are configured with a path to executable that is stored in an uncommon/unprotected folder location.
RiskDescription: An attacker can exploit this misconfiguration in order to change a service's executable to gain escalation of privileges and persistency on the machine.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Microsoft network client: Digitally sign communications (always)'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether packet signing is required by the SMB client component. If this is enabled, the SMB client will only communicate with an SMB server that performs SMB packet signing.
RiskDescription: Unsigned traffic exposes you to man-in-the-middle attacks. Attackers can potentially intercept and modify unsigned SMB packets and then modify the traffic and forward it so that the server might perform undesirable actions. Alternatively, the attacker could pose as the server or client after legitimate authentication and gain unauthorized access to data.

ConfigurationName: Fix Microsoft Defender for Endpoint sensor data collection for Linux
ConfigurationDescription: The Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service relies on sensor data collection to determine the security state of a machine.
RiskDescription: The Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service will not be able to determine the security state of machines that are not reporting sensor data properly.

ConfigurationName: Set IPv6 source routing to highest protection
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether IPv6 source routing is enabled.
RiskDescription: Configuring the system to disable IP source routing protects against spoofing.

ConfigurationName: Fix Microsoft Defender for Endpoint impaired communications
ConfigurationDescription: This status indicates that there's limited communication between the machine and the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service.
RiskDescription: Limited communication between the machine and the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service can lead to the service not being able to determine the security state of machine.

ConfigurationName: Set user authentication for remote connections by using Network Level Authentication to 'Enabled'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether to require user authentication for remote connections to the RD Session Host server by using Network Level Authentication.
RiskDescription: By completing user authentication before creating a remote desktop connection, Network-Level Authentication requires fewer remote computer resources and thus protects the remote computer from denial of service attacks. It also protects the remote computer from attacks that abuse accessibility features over login sessions.

ConfigurationName: Secure Home Folders in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: By default macOS allows all valid users into the top level of every networked user's home folder, with the ability to view the folder content. This control restricts access to a home folder to only the user, helping to protect against inadvertent information disclosures.
RiskDescription: Allowing all users to view the top level of all networked user's home folder may not be desirable since it may lead to the revelation of sensitive information.

ConfigurationName: Restrict anonymous access to named pipes and Shares
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether anonymous access is restricted to only shares and pipes that are named.
RiskDescription: Null sessions are a weakness that can be exploited through shares (including the default shares) on computers in your environment in order to gain unauthorized system access. Network shares can be accessed by any network user. This could lead to the exposure or corruption of sensitive data. This setting configures Windows to restrict anonymous access to only those shares and pipes listed in Network Access: named pipes that can be accessed anonymously.

ConfigurationName: Turn on Microsoft Defender Credential Guard
ConfigurationDescription:
Microsoft Defender Credential Guard uses virtualization-based security to isolate secrets so that only privileged system software can access them.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: If disabled, malicious attackers could potentially gain access to user credentials stored in memory and expose the machine to various types of attacks, such as pass-the-hash.

ConfigurationName: Block executable content from email client and webmail
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule blocks executable and script files (such as .exe, .dll, .scr, .ps, .vbs, .js) from launching from email in Microsoft Outlook or Outlook.com and other popular webmail providers.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Email attachments are the most common method that attackers use for transmitting malicious software and viruses into computers and organizations.

ConfigurationName: Block Office communication application from creating child processes
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule prevents Outlook from creating child processes, while still allowing legitimate Outlook functions.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Provides protection against social engineering attacks and prevents exploit code from abusing a vulnerability in Outlook, by blocking the launch of additional payload. It also protects against Outlook rules and forms exploits that attackers can use when a user's credentials are compromised.

ConfigurationName: Set minimum password length to 15 or more characters in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: Determines the minimum password length.
RiskDescription: The use of more characters in a password helps to exponentially increase the time and resources required to compromise the password.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'WDigest Authentication'
ConfigurationDescription: When the WDigest Authentication protocol is enabled, plain text passwords are stored in the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS) exposing them to theft.
RiskDescription: Disabling this setting will prevent WDigest from storing credentials in memory.

ConfigurationName: Turn on Tamper Protection
ConfigurationDescription:
Tamper Protection essentially locks Microsoft Defender for Endpoint and prevents your security settings from being changed through apps and methods such as editing registry values, changing settings through PowerShell cmdlets and editing or removing security settings through group policies.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later.
RiskDescription: Without enabling Tamper Protection, malicious apps can potentially change important Microsoft Defender for Endpoint settings, for example disable virus and threat protection, turn off real-time protection or disable cloud-delivered protection.

ConfigurationName: Enable Microsoft Defender Antivirus email scanning
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Microsoft Defender Antivirus analyzes the mail bodies and attachments and scans them for malicious content. MDMWinsOverGP configuration is not supported.
RiskDescription: Not scanning incoming emails and attachments could potentially enable attackers to deliver malicious content and attachments into the organization

ConfigurationName: Enable Set 'Domain member: Digitally encrypt secure channel data (when possible)'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether a domain member should attempt to negotiate encryption for all secure channel traffic that it initiates.
RiskDescription: When a computer joins a domain, a computer account is created. After it joins the domain, the computer uses the password for that account to create a secure channel with the domain controller for its domain every time that it restarts. Requests that are sent on the secure channel are authenticated and sensitive information such as passwords are encrypted but the channel is not integrity-checked, and not all information is encrypted.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Domain member: Digitally sign secure channel data (when possible)'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether a domain member should attempt to negotiate whether all secure channel traffic that it initiates must be digitally signed. Digital signatures protect the traffic from being modified by anyone who captures the data as it traverses the network.
RiskDescription: When a computer joins a domain, a computer account is created. After it joins the domain, the computer uses the password for that account to create a secure channel with the domain controller for its domain every time that it restarts. Requests that are sent on the secure channel are authenticated and sensitive information such as passwords are encrypted but the channel is not integrity-checked, and not all information is encrypted.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Installation and configuration of Network Bridge on your DNS domain network'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether a user can install and configure the Network Bridge. The Network Bridge allows users to create a layer 2 MAC bridge, enabling them to connect two or more network segments together.
RiskDescription: A Network Bridge can connect two or more network segments, allowing unauthorized access or exposure of sensitive data in another network segment.

ConfigurationName: Disable the built-in Administrator account
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether the built-in Administrator account is disabled.
RiskDescription: The built-in administrator account is a well-known account subject to attack by malicious actors. It cannot be locked out due to failed logons, which makes it a prime target for brute force attacks that attempt to guess passwords. Additionally, it has a well-known security identifier (SID) and there are third-party tools that allow authentication by using the SID rather than the account name,  meaning that even if the account is renamed, an attacker could launch a brute force attack by using the SID to log on

ConfigurationName: Set User Account Control (UAC) to automatically deny elevation requests
ConfigurationDescription: Determines the behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users.
RiskDescription: Denying elevation requests from standard user accounts requires tasks that need elevation to be initiated by accounts with administrative privileges. This prevents privileged account credentials from being cached with standard user profile information to help mitigate credential theft.

ConfigurationName: Disable SMBv1 client driver
ConfigurationDescription: Disabling SMBv1 support may prevent access to file or print sharing resources with systems or devices that only support SMBv1.
RiskDescription: SMBv1 is a legacy protocol that uses the MD5 algorithm as part of SMB. MD5 is known to be vulnerable to a number of attacks such as collision and preimage attacks as well as not being FIPS compliant.

ConfigurationName: Block Adobe Reader from creating child processes
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule prevents Adobe Reader from creating additional child processes.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Through social engineering or exploits, malware can download and launch additional payloads and break out of Adobe Reader.

ConfigurationName: Enable FileVault Disk Encryption in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: FileVault secures a system's data by automatically encrypting its boot volume and requiring a password or recovery key to access it. Encrypting the system hard drive ensures both confidentiality and integrity of any data stored on the system.
RiskDescription: Encrypting sensitive data minimizes the likelihood of unauthorized users gaining access to it. Mobile devices, laptops, desktops, and storage devices can be lost or stolen, and the contents of their data storage can be read, copied, or altered.

ConfigurationName: Block outdated ActiveX controls for Internet Explorer
ConfigurationDescription: This feature keeps ActiveX controls up to date and helps make them safer to use in Internet Explorer.
RiskDescription: Many ActiveX controls are not automatically updated as new versions are released. It is very important to keep ActiveX controls up to date because malicious or compromised webpages can target security flaws in outdated ActiveX controls.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Insecure guest logons' in SMB
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether insecure guest logons are used by file servers to allow unauthenticated access to shared folders.
RiskDescription: Insecure guest logons allow unauthenticated access to shared folders and retreive sensitive data, as well as place malicious files. Shared resources on a system must require authentication to establish proper access.

ConfigurationName: Fix Microsoft Defender for Endpoint impaired communications in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: This status indicates that there's limited communication between the machine and the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service.
RiskDescription: Limited communication between the machine and the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service can lead to the service not being able to determine the security state of machine.

ConfigurationName: Turn on Microsoft Defender Antivirus real-time protection for Linux
ConfigurationDescription: This status indicates that Microsoft Defender Antivirus real-time protection is disabled.
RiskDescription: Not having real-time protection enabled will cause important AV functionalities to not work.

ConfigurationName: Resume BitLocker protection on all drives
ConfigurationDescription:
BitLocker Drive Encryption is a data protection feature that integrates with the operating system and addresses the threats of data theft or exposure from lost, stolen, or inappropriately decommissioned computers.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1803 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Drives that aren't encrypted are exposed to unauthorized access to user data and to data tampering while the system is offline.

ConfigurationName: Block untrusted and unsigned processes that run from USB
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule allows admins to prevent unsigned or untrusted executable and script files (such as .exe, .dll, .scr, .ps, .vbs, .js) from running from USB removable drives, including SD cards.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Attackers often use removable devices for executing malicious code, even without the knowledge of the device owner.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Require domain users to elevate when setting a network's location'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether to require domain users to elevate when setting a network's location.
RiskDescription: Selecting an incorrect network location may allow greater exposure of a system

ConfigurationName: Disable running or installing downloaded software with invalid signature
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether downloaded software with invalid signature can be run or installed.
RiskDescription: An invalid signature might indicate that someone has tampered with the file, which could potentially enable an attacker to insert malicious code.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Domain member: Disable machine account password changes'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether automatic password changes are enforced on computer accounts.
RiskDescription: Disabling automatic password changes can make the system more vulnerable to malicious access. Frequent password changes can be a significant safeguard for your system.

ConfigurationName: Unrestricted Access Accounts for Linux
ConfigurationDescription: This settings makes sure that only "root" will have unrestricted access.
RiskDescription: Unrestriced Access Accounts posing a great threat as these account are not limited. This threat can be either explioted by malicious intents or even by non malicious honest mistakes caused by the user.

ConfigurationName: Enable Microsoft Defender Antivirus scanning of downloaded files and attachments
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Microsoft Defender Antivirus scans all downloaded files and attachments for malicious code.
RiskDescription: Not scanning downloaded files and attachments leaves devices vulnerable to malicious code penetration into the organization.

ConfigurationName: Set LAN Manager authentication level to 'Send NTLMv2 response only. Refuse LM & NTLM'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines which challenge/response authentication protocol is used for network logons. This choice affects the level of authentication protocol used by clients, the level of session security negotiated, and the level of authentication accepted by servers.
RiskDescription: Using older/weaker authentication levels (LM & NTLM) make it potentially possible for attackers to sniff that traffic to more easily reproduce the user's password.

ConfigurationName: Secure Microsoft Defender firewall private profile
ConfigurationDescription:
Microsoft Defender Firewall is designed to keep hackers and malicious software from gaining access to your device through a network or the Internet. Turn on to have Microsoft Defender Firewall use the settings for the Private Network profile to filter network traffic.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2008 R2, 2012 R2, 2016 and 2019.
RiskDescription: If the firewall is turned off all traffic will be able to access the system and an attacker may be more easily able to remotely exploit a weakness in a network service.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Allow running plugins that are outdated'
ConfigurationDescription:
Chrome enables the use of outdated plugins. By disabling this feature Chrome will not prompt the user to use an outdated plugin.
This security control is applicable for Google Chrome versions lower than 87.0.0.0
RiskDescription: Running the most up-to-date version of a plugin can reduce the possibility of running a plugin that contains an exploit or security hole.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Store LAN Manager hash value on next password change'
ConfigurationDescription: Controls whether or not a LAN Manager hash of the password is stored in the SAM the next time the password is changed.
RiskDescription: The LAN Manager hash uses a weak encryption algorithm and there are several tools available that use this hash to retrieve account passwords.

ConfigurationName: Set controlled folder access to enabled or audit mode
ConfigurationDescription:
This status indicated that controlled folder access is disabled. Controlled folder access helps protect files in key system folders from changes made by malicious and suspicious apps, including file-encrypting ransomware malware. Requires Microsoft Defender Antivirus Real-time protection.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Not enabling controlled folder access leaves you exposed to various attack vectors. Audit mode allows you to see audit events in the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint Machine timeline however it does not block suspicious applications. Consider enabling Controlled Folder Access for better protection.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Autoplay' for all drives
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Autoplay is enabled on the device. Autoplay starts to read from a drive as soon as you insert media in the drive, which causes the setup file for programs or audio media to start immediately
RiskDescription: An attacker could use this feature to launch a malicious program to damage a client computer or data on the computer.

ConfigurationName: Block abuse of exploited vulnerable signed drivers
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule prevents an application from writing a vulnerable signed driver to disk.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: In-the-wild, vulnerable signed drivers can be exploited by local applications - that have sufficient privileges - to gain access to the kernel. Vulnerable signed drivers enable attackers to disable or circumvent security solutions, eventually leading to system compromise.

ConfigurationName: Set 'Account lockout threshold' to 1-10 invalid login attempts
ConfigurationDescription:
Determines the number of failed logon attempts before the account is locked. The number of failed logon attempts should be reasonably small to minimize the possibility of a successful password attack, while still allowing for honest errors made during a legitimate user logon.

This security control is only assessed for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later.
RiskDescription: Setting an appropriate account lockout threshold helps prevents brute-force password attacks on the system.

ConfigurationName: Block process creations originating from PSExec and WMI commands
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule blocks processes through PsExec and WMI commands from running.

Warning: This rule is incompatible with management through System Center Configuration Manager because this rule blocks WMI commands the SCCM client uses to function correctly.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Attackers often use remote code execution for spreading malware attacks.

ConfigurationName: Set 'Minimum PIN length for startup' to '6 or more characters'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines the minimum PIN length for authentication without sending a password to a network where it could be compromised.
RiskDescription: BitLocker requires the use of the function keys [F1-F10] for PIN entry since the PIN is entered in the pre-OS environment before localization support is available. This limits each PIN digit to one of ten possibilities. The TPM has an anti-hammering feature that includes a mechanism to exponentially increase the delay for PIN retry attempts

ConfigurationName: Set 'Maximum password age' to '90 or fewer days, but not 0' in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: Determines the period of time (in days) that a password can be used before the system requires the user to change it.
RiskDescription: Setting this to less than 90 days (but not 0, which means it never expires) means an attacker has a limited amount of time in which to compromise a user's password and have access to your network resources.

ConfigurationName: Disable JavaScript on Adobe Acrobat Pro XI
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether to globally disable and lock JavaScript execution in Adobe Acrobat
RiskDescription: JavaScript could potentially be used by attackers to manipulate users or to execute undesired code locally.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Allow Basic authentication' for WinRM Service
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether the Windows Remote Management (WinRM) service accepts Basic authentication.
RiskDescription: Basic authentication uses plain text passwords that could be used by an attacker to compromise a system.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Limit local account use of blank passwords to console logon only'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether local accounts that are not password protected can be used to log on from locations other than the physical computer console. By enabling this configuration, local accounts that have blank passwords will not be able to log on to the network from remote client computers. Such accounts will only be able to log on at the keyboard of the computer.
RiskDescription: An account without a password can allow unauthorized access to a system as only the username would be required. Password policies should prevent accounts with blank passwords from existing on a system. However, if a local account with a blank password did exist, enabling this setting will prevent network access, limiting the account to local console logon only.

ConfigurationName: Turn off custom kernel/commandline in Windows Subsystem for Linux
ConfigurationDescription: Microsoft Defender for Endpoint plug-in for WSL does not support use of custom kernel/commandline in WSL2.
RiskDescription: MDE plug-in for WSL does not support custom kernel/commandline in WSL2. Visibility into activity in a Windows endpoint happening inside WSL2 containers running with custom kernels may be limited.

ConfigurationName: Enable scanning of removable drives during a full scan
ConfigurationDescription:
This setting controls whether or not to scan for malicious software and unwanted software in the contents of removable drives, such as USB flash drives, when running a full scan.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later.
RiskDescription: Scanning removable drives is extremely important, as they are more likely to contain malicious software and files brought into the enterprise managed environment from an external, unmanaged environment.

ConfigurationName: Turn on Microsoft Defender Antivirus
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Microsoft Defender Antivirus is configured to run and scan for malware and other potentially unwanted software.
RiskDescription: Not having a current, updated antivirus product scanning each computer for malicious file activity exposes the organization to malware or other potentially unwanted software.

ConfigurationName: Disable JavaScript on Adobe Reader DC
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether to globally disable and lock JavaScript execution in Adobe Reader
RiskDescription: JavaScript could potentially be used by attackers to manipulate users or to execute undesired code locally.

ConfigurationName: Enable Automatic Updates
ConfigurationDescription: Controls whether the Office automatic updates are enabled or disabled for all Office products installed by using Click-to-Run. This policy has no effect on Office products installed via Windows Installer.
RiskDescription: Security updates help prevent malicious attacks on Office applications. Timely application of Office updates helps ensure the security of devices and the applications running on the devices. Without these updates, devices and the applications running on those devices are more susceptible to security attacks.

ConfigurationName: Turn on Tamper Protection for MacOS
ConfigurationDescription:
Tamper protection in macOS helps prevent unwanted changes to security settings from being made by unauthorized users. Tamper protection helps prevent unauthorized removal of Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on macOS. This capability also helps important security files, processes, and configuration settings from being tampered.

.
RiskDescription: Without enabling Tamper Protection, malicious apps can potentially change important Microsoft Defender for Endpoint settings, for example disable virus and threat protection, turn off real-time protection or disable cloud-delivered protection.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts'
ConfigurationDescription: Controls the ability of anonymous users to enumerate the accounts in the Security Accounts Manager (SAM). If you enable this policy setting, users with anonymous connections will not be able to enumerate domain account user names on the systems in your environment.
RiskDescription: Anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts allows anonymous log on users (null session connections) to list all accounts names, thus providing a list of potential points to attack the system.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Configure Offer Remote Assistance'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether unsolicited offers of help to this computer via Remote Assistance are allowed. Help desk and support personnel will not be able to proactively offer assistance, although they can still respond to user assistance requests.
RiskDescription: A user might be tricked and accept an unsolicited Remote Assistance offer from a malicious user.

ConfigurationName: Turn on Microsoft Defender Firewall
ConfigurationDescription:
Microsoft Defender Firewall is designed to keep hackers and malicious software from gaining access to your device through a network or the Internet.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2008 R2, 2012 R2, 2016 and 2019.
RiskDescription: If the firewall is turned off all traffic will be able to access the system and an attacker may be more easily able to remotely exploit a weakness in a network service.

ConfigurationName: Set 'Account lockout duration' to 15 minutes or more
ConfigurationDescription:
Determines the length of time that must pass before a locked account is unlocked and a user can try to log on again. If configured to 0, accounts will remain locked out until an administrator manually unlocks them.

This security control is only assessed for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later.
RiskDescription: Setting an appropriate account lockout duration helps prevent brute-force password attacks on the system.

ConfigurationName: Turn on all system-level Exploit protection settings
ConfigurationDescription:
This status indicates that not all system-level Exploit Guard protection settings are enabled.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Not enabling all Exploit Guard protection settings could potentially leave your vulnerable to malicious exploit attacks.

ConfigurationName: Disable IP source routing
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether IP source routing is enabled.
RiskDescription: Configuring the system to disable IP source routing protects against spoofing.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Safe DLL Search Mode'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether an application searches for DLLs in the system path before searching the current working directory .
RiskDescription: An unauthorized DLL inserted by an attacker into an applications working directory could allow malicious code to be run on the system.

ConfigurationName: Block execution of potentially obfuscated scripts
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule prevents scripts that appear to be obfuscated from running. It uses the AntiMalwareScanInterface (AMSI) to determine if a script is potentially obfuscated, and then blocks such a script, or blocks scripts when an attempt is made to access them.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Malware and other threats can attempt to obfuscate or hide their malicious code in script files.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Network Protection'
ConfigurationDescription:
Network protection helps reduce the attack surface of your devices from Internet-based events. It prevents employees from using any application to access dangerous domains that may host phishing scams, exploits, and other malicious content on the Internet.
It expands the scope of Windows Defender SmartScreen to block all outbound HTTP(s) traffic that attempts to connect to low-reputation sources (based on the domain or hostname)

This security control is only assessed for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Not enabling Network Protection in block mode exposes your users and machines to phishing scams, as well as to internet delivered exploits and malicious content.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Password Manager'
ConfigurationDescription: If this setting is enabled, Chrome will memorize passwords and automatically provide them when a user logs into a site. By disabling this feature the user will be prompted to enter their password each time they visit a website.
RiskDescription: If not configured correctly, by using 3rd party app an intruder can dump the browser's stored passwords without having to open the browser, enter a password, or even to be identified as the attacked user.

ConfigurationName: Block Office applications from creating executable content
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule prevents Office apps, including Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, from creating executable content.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Creating executable content is a typical behavior where malware uses Office as a vector to break out of Office and save malicious code components to disk, where they persist and survive a computer reboot.

ConfigurationName: Update Microsoft Defender for Endpoint core components
ConfigurationDescription: Indicates that the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint EDR sensor (Windows Server 2012 R2, 2016) or Microsoft Defender for Endpoint agent (Linux, macOS) installed on the machine is not up to date.
RiskDescription: Having outdated components running on your machines could potentially leave you exposed to new types of attacks that might not be preventable or detectable by older versions. Older versions might also be missing critical response capabilities, as well as bug fixes, which were introduced in newer versions. Not being on the minimum required version for Linux and macOS especially could prevent Engine signature definitions from loading and lead to significant gaps in protection.

ConfigurationName: Enable Explorer Data Execution Prevention (DEP)
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Data Execution Prevention can be turned off for File Explorer.
RiskDescription: DEP provides additional protection by performing checks on memory to help prevent malicious code from running.

ConfigurationName: Block JavaScript or VBScript from launching downloaded executable content
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule prevents JavaScript and VBScript from being allowed to launch apps.

Note: This isn't a common line-of-business use, but line-of-business applications sometimes use scripts to download and launch installers.

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Malware written in JavaScript or VBS often acts as a downloader to fetch and launch additional native payload from the Internet.

ConfigurationName: Fix Microsoft Defender for Endpoint impaired communications for Linux
ConfigurationDescription: This status indicates that there's limited communication between the machine and the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service.
RiskDescription: Limited communication between the machine and the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service can lead to the service not being able to determine the security state of machine.

ConfigurationName: Remove insecure administration protocols SNMP V1 and SNMP V2
ConfigurationDescription: Devices using SNMP V1 or V2 are vulnerable because SNMP V1 and V2 are not encrypted or secure communication protocols.  Use a secure protocol such as SNMP V3 to administer devices.
RiskDescription: Devices using SNMP V1 or V2 are at increased risk of credential theft.

ConfigurationName: Enable System Integrity Protection (SIP) in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: System Integrity Protection restricts access to system domain locations and restricts runtime attachment to system processes. Any attempt to inspect or attach to a system process will fail. It’s vital to prevent unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources, protect audit tools from unauthorized access, modification, and deletion, limit privileges to change software resident within software libraries, limit the ability of non-privileged users to grant other users direct access to the contents of their home directories/folders.
RiskDescription: Running without System Integrity Protection on a production systems puts the system at risk of the modification of system binaries or code injection of system processes that would otherwise be protected by SIP.

ConfigurationName: Turn on real-time protection
ConfigurationDescription: This status indicates that Microsoft Defender Antivirus real-time protection is disabled.
RiskDescription: Not having real-time protection enabled will cause important AV functionalities to not work.

ConfigurationName: Set account lockout threshold to 5 or lower in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: Specifies the amount of times a user can enter an incorrect password before a lockout will occur.
RiskDescription: If not properly configured, the device is potentially exposed to brute-force password attacks on the system.

ConfigurationName: Block Office applications from injecting code into other processes
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule blocks code injection attempts from Office apps into other processes. There are no known legitimate business purposes for using code injection

This security control is only applicable for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Attackers might attempt to use Office apps to migrate malicious code into other processes through code injection, so the code can masquerade as a clean process and hide the activity from antivirus scanning engines.

ConfigurationName: Block webpages from automatically running Flash plugins
ConfigurationDescription:
Allows you to set whether websites are allowed to automatically run Flash plugin. Automatically running the Flash plugin can be either allowed for all websites or denied for all websites.
This security control is applicable for Google Chrome versions lower than 87.0.0.0
RiskDescription: Malicious Flash can cause browser instability and erratic behavior so setting the value to click to play will allow a user to only run necessary Flash plugin.

ConfigurationName: Turn on Microsoft Defender Antivirus PUA protection in block mode for Linux
ConfigurationDescription: Enabling Potentially Unwanted Application (PUA) protection in block mode will block and automatically quarantine potentially unwanted applications. PUA protection blocking takes effect on endpoint clients after the next signature update or computer restart.
RiskDescription: Not having PUA in Block mode enabled leaves your machines vulnerable to unwanted applications with potentially malicious behavior.

ConfigurationName: Disable JavaScript on Adobe Reader 2017
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether to globally disable and lock JavaScript execution in Adobe Reader 2017
RiskDescription: JavaScript could potentially be used by attackers to manipulate users or to execute undesired code locally.

ConfigurationName: Set 'Minimum password length' to '14 or more characters'
ConfigurationDescription:
Determines the minimum password length.

This security control is only assessed for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later.
RiskDescription: The shorter the password is, the lower the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.  Use of more characters in a password helps to exponentially increase the time and/or resources required to compromise the password.

ConfigurationName: Encrypt all BitLocker-supported drives
ConfigurationDescription:
BitLocker Drive Encryption is a data protection feature that integrates with the operating system and addresses the threats of data theft or exposure from lost, stolen, or inappropriately decommissioned computers.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1803 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Drives that aren't encrypted are exposed to unauthorized access to user data and to data tampering while the system is offline.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Always install with elevated privileges'
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Windows Installer always elevates privileges when installing applications.
RiskDescription: Standard user accounts must not be granted elevated privileges. Enabling Windows Installer to elevate privileges when installing applications can allow malicious persons and applications to gain full control of a system.

ConfigurationName: Turn on Microsoft Defender Antivirus PUA protection in block mode in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: Enabling Potentially Unwanted Application (PUA) protection in block mode will block and automatically quarantine potentially unwanted applications. PUA protection blocking takes effect on endpoint clients after the next signature update or computer restart.
RiskDescription: Not having PUA in Block mode enabled leaves your machines vulnerable to unwanted applications with potentially malicious behavior.

ConfigurationName: Set 'Reset account lockout counter after' to 15 minutes or more
ConfigurationDescription:
Determines the length of time before the 'Account lockout threshold' counter resets to zero after a failed logon attempt. This reset time must be less than or equal to the value of the 'Account lockout duration' setting.

This security control is only assessed for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later.
RiskDescription: Setting an appropriate account lockout counter helps prevent brute-force password attacks on the system.

ConfigurationName: Block Flash activation in Office documents
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Flash can be used in office documents.
RiskDescription: Flash is an unsecure technology with many known vulnerabilities, it is recommended to avoid using it.

ConfigurationName: Disable Flash on Adobe Acrobat Pro XI
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Adobe Acrobat will render Flash content.
RiskDescription: Flash is an unsecure technology with many known vulnerabilities, it is recommended to avoid using it.

ConfigurationName: Disable 'Continue running background apps when Google Chrome is closed'
ConfigurationDescription: Chrome allows for processes started while the browser is open to remain running once the browser has been closed. It also allows for background apps and the current browsing session to remain active after the browser has been closed. Disabling this feature will stop all processes and background applications when the browser window is closed.
RiskDescription: If this setting is enabled, vulnerable or malicious plugins, apps and processes can continue running even after Chrome has closed.

ConfigurationName: Ensure BitLocker drive compatibility
ConfigurationDescription:
BitLocker Drive Encryption is a data protection feature that integrates with the operating system and addresses the threats of data theft or exposure from lost, stolen, or inappropriately decommissioned computers.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1803 or later, and Windows Server 2019.
RiskDescription: Drives that aren't compatible with BitLocker remain not encrypted. Drives that aren't encrypted are exposed to unauthorized access to user data and to data tampering while the system was offline.

ConfigurationName: Fix Microsoft Defender for Endpoint sensor data collection
ConfigurationDescription: The Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service relies on sensor data collection to determine the security state of a machine.
RiskDescription: The Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service will not be able to determine the security state of machines that are not reporting sensor data properly.

ConfigurationName: Enable Gatekeeper in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: Gatekeeper is an application allow list control that restricts downloaded applications from launching, limiting applications from unverified sources from running without authorization.
RiskDescription: If Gatekeeper isn't enabled, your device is at a higher risk of being exposed to unauthorized or malicious applications running on the system.

ConfigurationName: Fix Microsoft Defender for Endpoint sensor data collection in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: The Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service relies on sensor data collection to determine the security state of a machine.
RiskDescription: The Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service will not be able to determine the security state of machines that are not reporting sensor data properly.

ConfigurationName: Disable JavaScript on Adobe Acrobat 2017
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether to globally disable and lock JavaScript execution in Adobe Acrobat 2017
RiskDescription: JavaScript could potentially be used by attackers to manipulate users or to execute undesired code locally.

ConfigurationName: Enable Microsoft Defender Antivirus cloud-delivered protection in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: Indicates that Microsoft Defender Antivirus cloud-delivered protection is not enabled. Cloud-delivered protection service provides very important protection against malware on your endpoints and across your network. Learn more about cloud-delivered protection
RiskDescription: The Windows Defender Antivirus cloud service (also referred to as Microsoft Advanced Protection Service - MAPS) is a mechanism for delivering updated protection to your network and endpoints. When cloud-deliverad protection is disabled, Microsoft AI and cloud resources cannot be harnessed to provide near real-time protection to your endpoints and the risk of new and emerging threats is increased.

ConfigurationName: Set 'Enforce password history' to '24 or more password(s)' in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: Determines the number of unique new passwords that are required before an old password can be reused in association with a user account.
RiskDescription: Password reuse is an important concern in any organization. Many users want to reuse the same password for their account over a long period of time.

ConfigurationName: Turn on Microsoft Defender Antivirus real-time protection in macOS
ConfigurationDescription: This status indicates that Microsoft Defender Antivirus real-time protection is disabled.
RiskDescription: Not having real-time protection enabled will cause important AV functionalities to not work.

ConfigurationName: Block credential stealing from the Windows local security authority subsystem (lsass.exe)
ConfigurationDescription:
Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules are the most effective method for blocking the most common attack techniques being used in cyber attacks and malicious software.
This ASR rule locks down LSASS.

This security control is only applicable for machines with LSA protection not running.
RiskDescription: Attackers can use tools like Mimikatz to scrape cleartext passwords and NTLM hashes from LSASS.

ConfigurationName: Secure Microsoft Defender Firewall domain profile
ConfigurationDescription:
Determines whether Microsoft Defender Firewall uses the settings for this profile to filter network traffic for the Domain Network profile.

This security control is only assessed for machines on Windows 10, version 1709 or later, and Windows Server 2008 R2, 2012 R2, 2016 and 2019.
RiskDescription: If the firewall is turned off all traffic will be able to access the system and an attacker may be more easily able to remotely exploit a weakness in a network service.

ConfigurationName: Disable the local storage of passwords and credentials
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether Credential Manager saves passwords or credentials locally for later use when it gains domain authentication.
RiskDescription: Locally cached passwords or credentials can be accessed by malicious code or unauthorized users.

ConfigurationName: Set 'Maximum password age' to '60 or fewer days, but not 0'
ConfigurationDescription:
Determines the period of time (in days) that a password can be used before the system requires the user to change it.

This security control is only assessed for machines with Windows 10, version 1709 or later.
RiskDescription: Setting this to less than 60 days (but not 0, which means it never expires) means an attacker has a limited amount of time in which to compromise a user's password and have access to your network resources.

ConfigurationName: Disable JavaScript on Adobe DC
ConfigurationDescription: Determines whether to globally disable and lock JavaScript execution in Adobe DC
RiskDescription: JavaScript could potentially be used by attackers to manipulate users or to execute undesired code locally.

ConfigurationName: Enable 'Local Security Authority (LSA) protection' on Windows 11 22h2 and higher
ConfigurationDescription: Forces LSA to run as Protected Process Light (PPL). Set value to 1 to enable LSA protection with a UEFI variable, Set value to 2 to enable LSA protection without a UEFI variable, only enforced on Windows 11 version 22H2 and later.
RiskDescription: If LSA isn't running as a protected process, attackers could easily abuse the low process integrity for attacks (such as Pass-the-Hash).

ConfigurationName: Require authentication for Telnet management interface
ConfigurationDescription: Telnet as a management interface allows admins to remotely manage devices. Without an authentication requirement, any user who has network access to these devices may compromise them. Update the device configuration to require authentication.
RiskDescription: Adversaries may be able to take full control of devices over the network if unauthenticated admin access is allowed.
